content.description: A bit of old Callahan history, this route is protected with fixed railroad spikes. As you climb synch a draw to each spike.
content.location: Sort northeast wall on uphill saddle of Shark Tooth Rock next to Shark Breath. Refer to Rock Climbing Western Oregon, Vol. 2: Umpqua map pages 66-67, photo and map 13 pages 169-170. and GPS coordinates in UTM's page 169.

content.description: Climb the bolted line up the left side corner of the rock as it rises off the ramp leading to Shark Rock. The crux is a dead-point of dyno to catch a hold onto the top.
content.location: Access from the uphill saddle leading out to Shark Rock. Refer to Rock Climbing Western Oregon, Vol. 2: Umpqua map pages 66-67, photo and map 13 pages 169-170. and GPS coordinates in UTM's page 169.

content.description: Belay from top anchors located to the right of Beyond Child's Play (looking out).
content.location: Refer to Rock Climbing Western Oregon, Vol. 2: Umpqua map pages 66-67, photo and map 13 pages 169-170. and GPS coordinates in UTM's page 169.

content.description: Climbs the valley side of the short pinnacle that sits on top the narrow ridge below the log landing and low angled sandstone dome. Follow bolts to the top with one crux move over the middle bulge. Crux can be aided if needed.
content.location: Refer to Rock Climbing Western Oregon, Vol. 2: Umpqua map pages 66-67, photo and map 13 pages 169-170. and GPS coordinates in UTM's page 169.

content.description: Hike downhill from landing to top anchors on the center right side of the sandstone dome (looking out). Belay this top rope from on top.
content.location: Refer to Rock Climbing Western Oregon, Vol. 2: Umpqua map pages 66-67, photo and map 13 pages 169-170. and GPS coordinates in UTM's page 169.

content.description: This is the largest cliff formation just north of Fantasy Island or which Shark Tooth Rock with its commanding view over the valley is the predominant feature. Shark Tooth Rock itself has two short routes ( 5.9 & 5.11a) from the uphill saddle but for the most part the southeast side remains unexplored and rarely visited. A large low angled and stepped sandstone dome sites to the north of Shark Rock. There are two short toprope routes worth noting on the south side of the dome (5.7 & 5.10a). From this dome a narrow ridge just out with a small pinnacle (5.7, A1) sitting on top this narrow ridge.
